pros: Remote work and above average PTO accrual
cons: IT has no laptops. Can use desktop at home in conjunction with meraki box or can use laptop to connect to an on-site server then connect to the on-site desktop. Very disorganized. Processes aren't documented. Network shares for the disorganized documentation. No wikis, no sharepoint, no cloud. Only hear from management when they think you've done something wrong even if it isn't warranted and no evidence exists. No room for process improvement. Keep your mouth shut and deal with the outdated processes. Pay is subpar and is way below industry standards. No business analysts and the "crms" bark orders instead of trying to assist the situation or resolution. Some of the rudest people I have ever worked with. Yours "christian" values but endorses pride month and transgenders which are anti-christian. Please remove christian as your affiliation. Worst company ever.

pros: Prob as good as anywhere but nursing is terrible.
cons: Always short staffed. Profits over mission. It’s always about how to do more with less nurses. It’s not like that with other disciplines bc they bring in money but for nurses we are an expense and it’s all about how to get by with the least amount of us regardless of how it impacts care and patients. New grads in charge. New grads with 7 and 8 patients as the norm. No one can say mission and patient care is priority.

review_title: CEO only cares about buying every small town clinic

They should know what I get paid and realize I can't afford this.

pros: Salary is best one will find for this job, but at a cost
cons: - All are negatives, except salary, being the only positive here, if you are an employed, rather than private physician (with privileges). The money is what causes retention - $$$$. - My colleagues all say- “They’ve got that right.” - Health insurance is horribly expensive and terrible, however, limited to local providers, a university facility if needed, restricting and denying many services. -Definitely location, so there’s an immediate penalty up front there, must be paid for in $$$$. -Lack of control over decision making , “over protocoled” robotic type, without thinking type environment, small roots, grown too big, too fast, without the right background/ experience in management, most are local, few from any large university trained programs - Patients cannot get specialty care for 6-12 months, however larger universities have mandatory appointments if you call within 1-2 weeks, with specialty care appointments within 1-2 weeks -It’s embarrassing that this system cannot do better with the way that they advertise themselves. I apologized to my patients all the time.

pros:
Great if you love to work in a patient-centric environment.  Would recommend working here for a year or two but in the last 10 years the politics have become so bad that a lot of people leave for other jobs within a few years.  Even though Linda White, the current CEO, is a fantastic person, she and management haven't done a good job with employee morale and satisfaction.  It used to be sky high under Ms. White's predecessor and prior management.  The economy took a turn south, but management also changed for the worse.  To add to this, they made a financial blunder in building the East Side Gateway Hospital, which caused major cutbacks in staff - many were laid off and they instituted a salary freeze for a few years.  Terrible decision making and judgement by DH management.  

.
cons: Way too many meetings - applies to all positions.  Meetings are deeply ingrained in Deaconess's culture.  If there's a slight need for clarification or disagreement, expect to be in a 15 to 30 min meeting.  This is how productivity goes down the drain.  DH used to have a warm culture that valued it's employees.  For instance, every year they had an employee picnic.  Now they rarely do things like that and the politics have become a lot more divisive.

pros: Every RT will work in critical care. Floor therapist is not an option. Overtime hours are always available. Great relationship between RTs and nursing.

job_title: Office Nurse/Clinical Office Assistant in Evansville, IN
pros:
Work within Deaconess Clinic (office), 
Location
Physicians and most staff I work with are dedicated and caring individuals who strive to help each patient regardless of anything else.

cons:
Clinic Nurse Salary is average to below average.
Clinic Management - things change with the wind, not reliable and I have learned not to trust them.
Benefits - the lack there off and the quality of the ones they do provide.
Increasing corporate mindset not as focused on the value of good employees.  
Increasing corporate emphasis of statistics and numbers vs care and quality of care - more about the $$.

review_title: Good place to work, but don't expect to advance unless you are friends with someone in management
pros: I enjoyed working for Deaconess because they do treat their employees well and benefits are good. 401k match is very nice. They promote helping your co-workers. I would work for this company again.
cons: The pay scale isn't flexible at all. The only way to make a decent rate is by working nights. If you aren't in with management or part of the clique you most likely won't advance in your position.

pros: You get $9/hr starting pay. From there it just depends on how much they feel they need you at the time.
cons: Working here i have witnessed a full assortment of unprofessional behavior from nursing and kitchen staff. Over the course of my time there I have endured harassment in the form of verbal hostility, both aggressive and passive outcomes of gossip pertaining to my personal life (hardly ever disclosed) and my work (which has affected my workload). I have even had one person follow me around the kitchen (immediately in rooms that I've left) and slander me for months at a time when i hardly ever work near her. This is a problem that is well known by many within the kitchen staff and supported my most if not all working there. There was even a mention to hold off on the hostility once when staffing was low again. Usually, management a part of the problem. I got the equivalent of a "F you," when i resigned. I've busted my butt there to support people who took advantage of me. I'm sure this tribal behavior continues on in my absence.

job_title: Phlebtomist and Laboratory Technician in Newburgh, IN
pros: Work alongside other healthcare professionals and get to interact with patients daily. Decent work/life balance the longer you work here. Get to work with little or no supervision and are expected to be competent enough to perform your position. Tuition reimbursement programs.
cons: Do not expect go get praise for going above and beyond your position. Operates with a no news is good news mentality from upper management. They are VERY strict with operating within scope of practice which is understandable in a healthcare setting but not for someone who wants to move forward. Opportunities for advancement are not advertised very well nor information available for how to even do so. Upper management gets irritated if you inquire on how to move forward/pick up further certifications and see it as a distraction away from your position. If you want to move forward in healthcare, you have to do it on your own time but they do help with college costs.

review_title: Has the playbook but rarely uses it.
job_title: Outpatient Services Supervisor in Evansville, IN
pros:
Depending on your value to the organization (i.e. nursing or physicians), the company takes incredibly good care of its staff.  

Multiple opportunities for employees to better their professional lives and career prospects within the organization if you know how and where to find them.
cons: Non-clinical staff are treated as expendable and rarely taken seriously or have a voice within the organization.  You can frequently learn more about the organization from the local media than you can from leadership.  Lacks any significant efforts at transparency or efforts to modernize operations.

pros: In the beginning of employment (2005) the management at DH focused on teamwork, and came down from there offices to help when needed. Great bunch to work with and for.
cons: New management is younger, inexperienced, immature, and systematically has pushed out anyone who does not hold a Bachelors Degree. It does not even have to pertain to the job, just as long as you can prove you are a BS.

pros: wages, opportunity, people Deaconess has been in a period of volatility. People have been wondering and answers were slow, not because there was a secrecy, but because there weren't actually answers. Overall I feel that they management shared what they could when it became information and not just speculation.
cons: company has gone through much transition. Work environment is mostly union except rns. The sister hospital nurse are still union. This has pros and cons, but I do not get the impression that there is any one trying to keep answers from people unnecessarily. Despite some difficult transition staff and management are trying to reach the same goals.

pros: The company culture is a rare family environment.. Everyone really is considered family and the company truly care's about their employees. They want what's best for the company however they reward and care about those that make it great. The company is based upon great structure and values.  There are numerous programs and perks that come alone with employment. It is a large company, therefore lots of room for advancement. Deaconess supports the advancement of their employees. Deaconess continues to grow and is the largest employer in the tri-state. Clinically speaking, there is plenty to brag about.
cons: Benefits could be improved upon.

review_title: Laboratory management needs to be replaced.
pros: Stable company with fair benefits. Salaries are the highest in the tristate area. Going in the right direction with instrumentation.
cons: Laboratory management is severely lacking. They tend to recognize only those who "obey" and throw the rest to the wolves. The Gateway campus is severely understaffed and management cannot get a good grip on the problem because they rarely go to that campus. We are treated better at the main campus because our needs are seen.  Communication is severely lacking.

pros: Management is very supportive and positive, offering encouragement.  The company is great to offer education reimbursement.  The company does much to help the community which feels good to be a part of.
cons: Lack of flexibility with scheduling for new graduates, pretty much full time rotating shifts or straight nights only available.  Short staffed often, nurses stretched too thin with a very heavy patient load on night shift with few assistive personnel

review_title: I only worked part-time on the weekends, so my experience is limited.
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Evansville, IN
pros: This company offers benefits to those with part-time employment, and pays for all required immunizations.
cons: This facility is chronically short-staffed on weekends, meaning that I usually did not get a break even during 12-hour shifts unless I first covered for a coworker by being responsible for up to 20+ patients for 1/2 hour.  Needless to say, I opted to not go on break.  Also, yearly raises are very nominal, and it is very difficult to receive a good review based on new rating systems.

review_title: Worked here eighteen years as an RN. Basically a good experience. Raises weren't as good the last several years.
pros: Opportunity for overtime.  Competitive pay for RN's. Offer decent benefits.  Nurses make own 6 week schedule as long as all shifts are covered within staffing requirement guidelines.
cons: Raises completely dependent on score made on performance evaluation. Therefore, some nurses with less experience and education make more per hour than more experienced nurses dependent on supervisor's evaluation.

review_title: Retirees and rejects welcome.  Be sure to leave paper trails and trust no one.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Some of the people really knew what they were doing and were easy going.
cons: Lots of red tape and miscommunication created hurt feelings and ego trips all over that place.  Not your most efficient hospital that is for sure.

pros: In Information Technology, there is never a shortage of work. Help Desk is very efficient at resolving most issues immediately.
cons: You are replaceable no matter how long or well you have done your job. It's almost impossible to get re-hired, no matter how qualified you are for the position.

job_title: Patient Intake Specialist in Evansville, IN
pros: Getting your foot in the door can lead to multiple opportunities within the hospital. There are bonus opportunities for certain departments monthly. Working with patients and families was always a plus.
cons: Keeping the job is the rough part. Attendance is extremely strict, they are crazy about call in’s and the probationary period is 6 MONTHS??! No PTO FOR 6 MO!!! Pay remains the same for a year unless you move positions. Management/HR KNOWS you’re replaceable and WILL treat you that way.

review_title: Great workplace, but didn't enjoy my temporary position and wasn't allowed to move throughout the department
pros: Staff is incredibly friendly, has a lot of company events to get to know everyone and give back to the community, great pay
cons: Orientation is long and boring, the way you have to log your hours is a pain to do every day, don't get much time off,

pros: Great company. Great benefits. Quality care. Oppurtunity for advancement in most roles. Nurses are treated with respect from physicians. Evidence based  practice.
cons: The "clinic" side of the company needs to ditch the Welborne Clinic way of operations and base its model off of the "hospital" side of the company. The clinic  seems to be chasing its tail while the hospital is utilizing the latest EBP, participating in EBP/research projects, etc.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
I work with a wonderful group of ladies who have excellent values and great work ethic.
We pray together, have devotion time and generally support each other at all times.
cons: It's almost impossible to receive a salary increase.  The last few years the raises have been less than 1%.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The disorganization allowed for a lot of unlisted perks from your boss/admins. Free food, time on the clock to do personal paperwork. Also the ability to adjust your schedule far more than any other hospital I had ever worked for. Just tell the admin you needed extra hours or couldn't work and if you were friends they would make it happen.
cons: The disorganization led to being drug-tested several times because meds would go missing, Also an aide got beaten by a patient because there wasn't enough staff on duty. As well as a lot of cronyism.

job_title: Night Shift Ambassador in Evansville, IN
pros: Well, the wage is $10/hr which is very good. The environment is clean, warm, and air conditioned.
cons: The management is a little shaky, and it is supposed to change soon. Also the schedule sometimes leaves necessary positions unstaffed for a shift. Plus, day shift gets automatic preference instead of night shift.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Evansville, IN
pros: Good hours flexible with school or family. Decent insurance benefits. Tuition reimbursement in some programs.
cons: Lots of hostile co workers, stress on the floor can be extremely disrespectful, rude and unprofessional towards patients and each other management can be clueless

pros: Many departments for potential growth; Good location; Centrally located in City with additional satellite locations; Some flexible schedules; Equipment good.
cons: Management is somewhat political in the way they operate; Can find roadblocks when trying to complete projects based on other people's priorities.

pros: Great Benefits: Health Insurance, Vacation time, 401k matching, no wait time for benefits.  Important work
cons: Leadership doesn't listen to employees.  Thinning staff for no apparent reason while gaining affiliates to support.  Little pay increase and little meaningful recognition from leadership.  False statements and promises from leadership.

review_title: It was a little rocky at first related to management but it was great because I know the sought out to do better.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Working relationship and teamwork. Pay was ok but I learned a great deal of knowledge.
cons: Organization, clicks, and sometimes hard work was overlooked and seldom recognized.

review_title: Nice people and easy but boring
pros: Good starting pay, easy work, no experience required, fun work environment, flexible hours, laid back, easy to learn, good for college students.
cons: No room to grow, pay isn't much better for people who worked here for 10 years, boring at times, very routine.

pros: Fantastic support from administration. Tuition reimbursement available. Opportunity for advancement. Availability to transfer within allows advancement opportunity.
cons: Department managers reporting directly to VP's without a director to hold them accountable for their actions... allows for micro management opportunity and a negative work environment.

review_title: Not a bad job. Hard to advance in certain departments. Pay is decent. Get pto every check.
pros: There are benefits. There is PTO every paycheck. Friendly environment. They work with you on scheduling.  You get insurance. iii
cons: The pay here is decent. They kind of under pay their employees in certain departments. Management can be bad in certain areas.

pros: Great employer!!  Great benefits!!  Works with staff regarding scheduling. Physicians willing to teach at every available opportunity!  Tuition reimbursement available.
cons: Some department managers have poor communication with staff.  Must wear designated colored scrubs which isn’t horrible, but I love wearing my company t-shirts to work.

job_title: Float Pool With Chs, Hma, and Integris in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: There are some great people at deaconess
cons: all hospitals are reeling with all the recent health care changes it is a struggle to stay up to date

pros: It qualifies for the PUBLIC SERVICE LOAN FORGIVENESS program.
cons: If you volunteer for extra time, they force you to take "on call" later in the week if they don't need you. You have to use their family pharmacy for prescriptions or you have to pay extra or full price, which is totally inconvenient.

review_title: I was hired for a customer service position at Deaconess Hospital.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Billings, MT
pros: Deaconess Hospital offers a mediocre benefit package but some perks are offered for employees.
cons: Deaconess Hospital wages in customer service are quite low and insurance package is mediocre. Training is poor.

pros: Knowledgeable and good information for learning care in this field. Would highly recommend if you want a good learning experience with lots of time
cons: Salary is tough to deal with if you don't have other source of income like spouse parent brother sister or savings

job_title: Help Desk Coordinator in Spokane, WA
pros:
Regular Schedule
All work is done independently
Mostly simple calls about desktop issues and pw resets
cons:
Not much versatility in position movement
Not likely to get a raise

review_title: Good values, driven by evidence based practice
pros: They care about employees. Patient safety is number one. Leading technology. Great staff that cares about patients and their outcomes.
cons: The pay could be better. I think this area of the country in general could pay nurses better. Not many cons

pros: They train phlebotomy skills and work with student schedules. DSS pay is pretty decent as well.
cons: The lab managerial staff is extremely cliqueish and gossips constantly about co-workers. It was not a very team-oriented environment.

review_title: Was very nice at the beginning, however cost saving and budgetary concerns were put before saving lives and patient care
pros: The fellow associates supported each other.
cons: Human resources do not keep matters confidential, they are not there for the "employee" just the bottom line.

review_title: Bad management, good incentives & hourly pay isn’t great
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Newburgh, IN
pros: The co-workers were amazing and insurance was good.
cons: The amount of work the expect for the pay they give you doesn’t match.

pros: I work at Deaconess because we are industry leaders in innovation.  The organization is forward thinking, engaging, and promotes personal growth.
cons: Downsides to working at Deaconess include only the same downsides of working in healthcare which include escalating regulation.

pros: Small, Friendly, a great place to work 1980-1992
cons: Was not a lot of opportunity for advancement, professionally or financially. Eventually folded due to their inability to garner a relationship with a hospital network.

pros: good co-workers that get along well both on the job and outside of work  ever changing work environment with lots of challenges
cons: must work different shifts, weekends and holidays

pros: Good comradery with coworkers. Great teamwork.
cons: Management does not care about nursing staff.

pros: The people are great and kind. Depending on the shift you work, your shift can go by quickly.
cons: You're required to work a certain amount of holidays. It can be a high stress job.

pros: The nursing staff has a culture of caring not only for our patients,  but for our coworkers.
cons: Short staffed at times, difficult to get team leaders to help on the floor.

pros: They hire good people.  They are proactive and responsive on pay levels.
cons: Do not  have safety net  when  there are call ins

review_title: Great benefits, not a lot of upward mobility
pros: Fun atmosphere, passionate management, great benefits
cons: Security department lacks upward mobility, tight budget/low raises - but decent pay for the job

pros: Family atmosphere, job security, community involvement, benefits, pay
cons: The pay is decent, could be looked at in some areas

job_title: Critical Care Technician in India, TN
pros: educational opportunities, fair pay, room for growth
cons: terrible benefits packages, have to get any prescriptions from Deaconess pharmacy (unrealistic fill/pick up time, have to enter building, can take DAYS to refill scripts)

pros: Excellent surgeons, staff, opportunity to take as much call as you wanted
cons: Cafeteria was horrible, some instruments were old and needed upgraded

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Plentiful hours available 
Decent pay
cons:
Poor management 
Lack of clear goals/guidelines
Staff is not shown respect by management

pros: good company to work for, opportunities to get involved within the system
cons: seems to have high turnover in some departments

pros: Always knew what was expected for my job.
cons: Personal growth was always available.

pros: Growing Company; Awesome CEO; Job Security
cons: No personal game plan; Feeling of a worker bee

pros: Great benefits, perks, and people
cons: Low wages with little to no hope for raises

pros:
Competitive pay
Great benefits (when I was there)
cons: Staffing needed a little extra boost

review_title: Working at Deaconess Hospital has been a rewarding, learning, enjoyable experience.
pros: My boss and coworkers are enjoyable to work with.
cons: I would like to be full time.

pros: Team was very helpful in teaching me more about biomedical equipment and in showing other departments like radiology.
cons: Do not recall any at the moment.

pros: Can be a great place to work at times.
cons: Leadership often misses the mark by assuming rather than asking and observing.

pros: OK pay, little supervision, flexible
cons: Not good benefits, useless teams that should provide support but are unreachable.

pros: Excellent at working around college schedule.
cons: Compensation wasn't excellent and no benefits for DSS employees.

pros: Weekend option pay and self scheduling.
cons: Few opportunities for the seasoned staff.

pros: Good company that puts a lot back in for employees

pros: Flexible hours and willing to work with college schedule
